results.title: [Remix: Sunnies]
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, ACMI and ACMI Collections
results.brief_description:
Worn at the beach or on a bush walk, or simply as a style statement, this playful short film is a tribute to the fashion accessory, and sun-smart, sun glasses. Set to a boss nova soundtrack, this short work is a tribute to ‘shades’, showing people wearing sun glasses cut from home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection. Featured are some of fashion’s best styles of eye wear from the 1940s to the 1970s.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office; Elenor Peach; Barry Parsons; The Gadsden Family and Neville Daley.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 29]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is about a trip around North Queensland to locations such as Townsville and National Parks. Wallace films the wonderful brolga water birds of the title but also captures the dramatic Wallaman Falls in Girringun Park, which is Australia’s highest permanent single drop waterfall, and the Little Crystal Creek Bridge on Mount Spec Rd in Paluma Range National Park. The bridge and Mt Spec Road are of particular interest as both are listed heritage sites on the Queensland Heritage Register and were constructed during the Great Depression in the 1930s using mostly unskilled labour and with the application of ‘Unemployment Relief Scheme’ funds. Mt Spec Road remains substantially intact throughout the 18km of its length and demonstrates an extensive and now uncommon use of concrete arch culverts, dry stone walling and stone-paved gutters. Also, the very picturesque bridge is the only identified concrete arch bridge dressed with stone remaining in service in Queensland.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Where Brolgas Dance’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:00:27:00 the ‘Air Cloud’ tour boat moored at a pier
00:00:32:00 looking out from the pier over a lake or river followed by boats sitting on sand and mud when the tide is out and remains of old jettys
00:01:03:00 views of boats moored at jettys and piers
00:02:09:00 sunflowers in the foreground of mountains
00:02:27:00 the ‘Burdekin Bridge’ rail and car bridge in Queensland
00:03:38:00 sugar cane, wetlands and lily pads and roaming cattle
00:04:13:00 a large spider web in the wetlands complete with black spider in the middle
00:04:30:00 driving through Townsville in Queensland, and past the ‘T&G Building’
00:06:13:00 views of brolgas standing in grass and flying overhead
00:07:52:00 signs for ‘Mt Spec National Park’ and ‘Little Crystal Creek’
00:07:59:00 views of the Little Crystal Creek Bridge and the creek itself with its lovely rocky banks
00:08:24:00 a roadside picnic and exploring under the bridge
00:08:54:00 sign for ‘McClelland Bridge’ followed by scenic views of mountains and waterways
00:10:06:00 driving through the rainforest
00:10:48:00 views of the dramatic Wallaman Falls
00:11:01:00 sign for the Falls with facts and information for campers
00:11:34:00 sightseers at a lookout
00:12:03:00 a small modest road bridge
00:12:16:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This short silent film consists of a staged interview between a man and a woman, seated in a 1950s or 1960s lounge setting with diamond patterned wallpaper in the background. There is also a short snippet of crowds of people at an exhibition.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains footage of a visit to the Gresswell Sanatorium in Mont Park, Victoria, which at the time housed and treated male patients with tuberculosis. Mont Park was an area north-east of Melbourne comprising several health institutions, including the Gresswell Sanatorium which was named after Dan Gresswell, a public health administrator. The film provides an insightful look at life in the sanatorium, including recreational activities and health care.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 great example of a handpainted sign reading ‘Repatriation Sanatorium, Drive Slow, Gresswell Sanatorium’
00:00:13:00 a 1940s style bus with logo ‘Heidelberg Motor Omnibus Service Pty. Ltd.’
00:00:40:00 a woman in 1940s style dress disembarks the bus
00:01:22:00 three men walking down the road
00:01:58:00 a man using a grinding wheel in a work shed
00:03:11:00 meal time at the sanatorium
00:04:07:00 a cheeky group of people in conversation, with several poking their tongue out to the camera
00:06:18:00 playing cricket with branches amongst the trees
00:07:22:00 a patient being treated with an injection and valve, presumably to relieve air from the lung, a common treatment for tuberculosis at the time
00:08:56:00 nurse in uniform of the era with a long veil

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a family holiday, including scenes of a campground beside a river and a trip to Sydney. It includes some great footage of the Sydney Opera House under construction, seen from Sydney Harbour.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 weatherboard house with roses in the front yard
00:00:54:00 a campground with tents and caravans
00:02:34:00 an Aboriginal child looking at the camera shyly
00:04:36:00 the Sydney Opera House under construction, seen from the harbour
00:05:41:00 on a ferry across Sydney Harbour

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film takes place during a trip to Port Moresby in Papua New Guinea. The film shows members of the Royal Papua Yacht Club sailing on the harbour, from the perspective of another yacht.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 view of building painted with sign ‘Royal Papua Yacht Club’
00:00:11:00 yachts sailing on the water, including close ups of rigging and sails and what appears to be a bamboo mast
00:00:39:00 group of men on a yellow sailing yacht, filmed from yacht alongside
00:00:52:00 yachts sailing on the harbour from different vantage points: in some shots open sea can be seen in the background; in others the cliffs of the harbour and the buildings of the city of Port Moresby
00:01:35:00 we see a man seated on the deck of the boat, smiling at the camera while adjusting ropes in the wind
00:02:16:00 a second man in a short sleeve shirt releasing a large floating buoy onto the water over the side of the boat; the buoy is decorated with the classic shield logo of BP (formerly British Petroleum), with yellow initials on a green shield design
00:02:32:00 the man is now seated on the edge of the boat while a third man cleans a firearm
results.description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film takes place during a trip to Port Moresby in Papua New Guinea. The film shows members of the Royal Papua Yacht Club sailing on the harbour, from the perspective of another yacht.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 view of building painted with sign ‘Royal Papua Yacht Club’
00:00:11:00 yachts sailing on the water, including close ups of rigging and sails and what appears to be a bamboo mast

00:00:52:00 yachts sailing on the harbour from different vantage points: in some shots open sea can be seen in the background; in others the cliffs of the harbour and the buildings of the city of Port Moresby
00:01:35:00 we see a man seated on the deck of the boat, smiling at the camera while adjusting ropes in the wind
00:02:16:00 a second man in a short sleeve shirt releasing a large floating buoy onto the water over the side of the boat; the buoy is decorated with the classic shield logo of BP (formerly British Petroleum), with yellow initials on a green shield design
00:02:32:00 the man is now seated on the edge of the boat while a third man cleans a firearm

group_siblings.title: [Donald Duck in Matching Tricks; The Charging Bull]

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film contains family gatherings for birthdays and weddings as well as Christmas in 1979, a picnic in the Eastern Gardens in Geelong, a trip to Cairns and a tennis tournament in Launceston, Tasmania. There are several gatherings for family birthdays, one of which is Dorothy Nixon’s 50th celebrations.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 extended family members enjoying a buffet meal at one of the family’s homes
00:00:55:00 family members pose for the camera in a backyard
00:01:36:00 extended family members at a long lunch table
00:02:23:00 arrivals to and/or departures from a family gathering
00:03:28:00 family members at the beach
00:03:43:00 the camera catches family members taking photos of a family gathering
00:04:24:00 filming the photographer
00:04:38:00 Stuart, with a mouth full of braces, grinning at the camera in his school uniform
00:04:49:00 Karen, Stuart and Les in their tennis gear
00:05:06:00 Dorothy in bed with Stuart and Karen visiting
00:05:18:00 a Labrador puppy eating in a garden
00:05:42:00 one of the family infants pretends to drink from a beer bottle at a family gathering
00:06:32:00 Les caught on camera at a sunny family picnic or barbeque gathering
00:07:30:00 shorts and long socks: a 1970s fashion look
00:07:57:00 at the barbeque
00:08:33:00 a family birthday party
00:09:30:00 views around the Nixon family home
00:09:58:00 birthday party inside the house
00:11:13:00 the extended family picnicking in a park
00:12:38:00 the 1970s three legged barbeque
00:12:52:00 feeding bread to the seagulls
00:13:50:00 views of the large family picnic including a 1960s green picnic case
00:14:50:00 views of children at the family picnic in the park
00:15:51:00 playing cricket at the picnic
00:16:44:00 looking out over scenery to some mountains
00:17:25:00 Dorothy walking by a palm tree in a lush park followed by a waterfall
00:18:06:00 filming from a train travelling through mountainous green countryside including waterfalls
00:18:45:00 arriving at Kuranda Rail Station in north Queensland.
00:18:53:00 views of orchids at the ‘Tropical Orchid Gardens at Beautiful Tinaroo’
00:20:52:00 waterbirds
00:21:12:00 ‘Ben Cropp’s Shipwreck Museum’
00:21:24:00 boats along a pier
00:21:31:00 feeding – and teasing – a crocodile for a rapt audience at an animal park
00:22:26:00 up close to some cassowaries at an animal park
00:23:50:00 a yellow sightseeing vessel sitting at the pier followed by views of the ocean floor through the glass bottom of the boat
00:25:11:00 a sandy shallow beach
00:25:40:00 Dorothy sitting on a rocky beach and in close up
00:25:54:00 a crocodile and some sharks in separate small enclosures
00:26:05:00 a motel swimming pool setting
00:26:35:00 motor boating down a river
00:27:40:00 fields under cultivation and a tourist bus
00:27:53:00 a rocky cascading river
00:27:59:00 a view looking across the wing of a ‘Qantas VH-TJO Lorikeet’ airplane
00:28:09:00 teenage Stuart in the backyard at home and with Dorothy
00:28:26:00 Stuart being camera shy in an airport waiting room
00:29:13:00 ‘Ansett VH-RMO Boeing 727’ airplane taking off

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

Their children having grown up, this film captures Les and Dorothy enjoying a holiday in New Zealand.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Dorothy Nixon and two companions are part of a travel trip as indicated by their name tags
00:00:17:00 sign for ‘trial plots’ as part of a nursery in New Zealand, followed by Dorothy enjoying some views of public gardens
00:01:12:00 sign for ‘Cockayne Memorial Garden’ in honour of Dr Leonard Cockayne, a significant botanist in New Zealand
00:01:31:00 a conservatory in the gardens
00:02:00:00 a large lake amongst hills and a ship, a yacht and boats
00:02:13:00 views toward snowy covered mountains and looking down over a town from a higher vantage point followed by more snowy mountain tops
00:03:07:00 a tourist bus stopped at a roadside lookout point followed by more lakeside scenery
00:03:30:00 filming the mountains and landscape from inside a small plane
00:04:19:00 views of the motel accommodation for the travellers
00:05:10:00 sign for the ‘Omarama Motel Lodge’
00:05:34:00 a peacock, several small deer
00:06:01:00 sign ‘Welcome to Lake Manapouri’
00:06:20:00 a waterfall and tourists on a walk bridge over ‘Falls Creek’
00:06:45:00 filming from a bus as it travels through mountains
00:07:19:00 filming among fellow tourists in a boat on a river taking in the spectacular views of waterfalls and mountains
00:09:42:00 a steam train comes into view on a country track followed by views of houses and trees across a lake
00:10:18:00 looking at the front of a paddle steamer
00:10:40:00 filming from a sky lift as it travels up a hill followed by views over a town below
00:11:11:00 looking at the sky lift as it travels up
00:11:24:00 tourists walk over a bridge looking down at a fast moving creek or river
00:12:52:00 a helicopter landing
00:13:52:00 views of ‘Shantytown’, a tourist attraction on the South Island
00:14:41:00 on board a tourist boat on a lake
00;15:21:00 sign for ‘New Zealand Electricity’ after views of the plant
00:15:27:00 various ‘Wharenui’ (Maori meeting house) followed by views of hot springs
00:16:16:00 on a light plane travelling over a lake looking down on a seaplane
00:17:12:00 memorial to ‘Michael Joseph Savage 1872 – 1940’
00:17:20:00 traditional Maori dance performance
00:18:04:00 scenes of the rolling waves around the rocky coast
00:18:28:00 the travellers gather at the sign for ‘Tane Mahuta (Lord of the Forest)’, a very tall tree
00:18:30:00 the bus tour passengers, including Len and Dorothy, bid each other farewell, followed by travelling by taxi to the airport and ‘Quantas’ and ‘Air New Zealand’ planes at the terminals

00:12:52:00 a helicopter landing
00:13:52:00 views of ‘Shantytown’, a tourist attraction on the South Island
00:14:41:00 on board a tourist boat on a lake
00;15:21:00 sign for ‘New Zealand Electricity’ after views of the plant
00:15:27:00 various ‘Wharenui’ (Maori meeting house) followed by views of hot springs
00:16:16:00 on a light plane travelling over a lake looking down on a seaplane
00:17:12:00 memorial to ‘Michael Joseph Savage 1872 – 1940’
00:17:20:00 traditional Maori dance performance
00:18:04:00 scenes of the rolling waves around the rocky coast
00:18:28:00 the travellers gather at the sign for ‘Tane Mahuta (Lord of the Forest)’, a very tall tree
00:18:30:00 the bus tour passengers, including Len and Dorothy, bid each other farewell, followed by travelling by taxi to the airport and ‘Quantas’ and ‘Air New Zealand’ planes at the terminals

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film features a parade of cars, trucks and buses in Ballarat and a visit to a swimming pool where Jack includes some special effects of diving into the pool. There is also a scene where two women are posing for the camera next to a car. It becomes evident that the older stately woman is shy of the camera but the endearing younger woman is very confident as she clowns around in her very 1940s trousers and beret outfit.

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a parade of vehicles in Ballarat
00:00:50:00 two women stand in front of a car; one is joking around for the camera
00:01:05:00 at a swimming pool, a group of women onlookers watch a men diving into the water; the motion is reversed in a special effect so that we watch the diving in and back out of the pool
00:02:25:00 swimmers give an exhibition of the Australian Crawl (freestyle)

results.title: Brett Whiteley
results.brief_description:
The Frank Eidlitz Collection contains the 16mm and 35mm film work of graphic designer and visual artist Frank Eidlitz (1923–1997), predominantly made during a Winston Churchill Fellowship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Cambridge in 1966. The collection contains Eidlitz’s experiments with light, movement and technology in film.

This short film by Frank Eidlitz shows a snippet of Australian artist Brett Whiteley at home with his wife Wendy and daughter Arkie. It was likely filmed in late 1966 or early 1967, before the Whiteleys moved to New York in late 1967. The film shows the artist and his family at home in the evening, reading the newspaper and watching television. Whiteley’s paintings line the walls of the living space, including ‘Fidgeting with Infinity’ (1966), a large triptych painting that dominates the space.

The film is dark and at times blurry.
